ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: The class was a virtual seminar, plus weekly recorded lectures through the DS program.
Lecture with two weely seminars.
Online lecture
Virtual seminars were paired with virtual lectures released at the start of every week.
Recorded lecture
Recorded lecture
Twice weekly virtual seminars and one weekly asynchronous lecture

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Knowledge: a good understanding of early philosophers, especially Plato and Aristotle.  Skills: ability to read complex philosophical texts, better logical and analytical thinking, how to take apart an argument and respond to it, how to write a philosophy paper.

My seminar participation became much more skillful, in my opinion: the seminar was full of really smart students, and I learned when to hold back and how to make my points effectively. Charles helps you in this way. I learned how to evaluate and critique philosophical arguments with rigor and charity. I learned how to write and think in an entirely new and exciting way. I studied texts that blew me away.
Writing skill
Philosophy teaches you to break every argument to its very brutal bones--to examine every argument in all its merits, flaws, and promises.

I gained knowledge of the foundational texts of Western philosophy and the different schools of philosophical thought they belong to. I learned how to rigorously deconstruct and critique an argument step by step, as well as how to write an essay analyzing a philosophical argument.

I gained great insight into philosophical ideas starting from Socrates and spanning to Aquinas. I feel that I greatly improved my ability to dissect philosophical arguments, and create queries of my own.

My class with David taught me the basics of ancient philosophical thought, running briskly but engagingly past the ideas of Plato, Aristotle, the Stoics, Epicureans, and postclassical thinkers. At a primitive level we were introduced to various key starting points of philosophical discussion which we had the opportunity to develop and debate in class, such as whether knowledge is attainable, the existence and nature of God, the basic foundation of reality, etc. Most of all, I think David taught me to break down arguments into their constituent premises and dissect them by evaluating their foundational assumptions.
I'm better at breaking arguments down into their components and understanding what makes them strong. I also now have a strong knowledge base from which to proceed with the study of philosophy.
Most importantly, improvement on the ability to evaluate an argument and break it down into it's key assumptions.
I learned how to write a philosophy essay and reconstruct arguments, which was completely new to me. I also learned about the important writers of ancient philosophy.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: I think the philosophy strand does a particularly good job of having a manageable and worthwhile reading load.  I also think DS does a great job with writing support.  Lastly, David Charles is an incredible professor.

I think the shift between the Plato and Aristotle readings and the other readings was a little abrupt-- we went from spending weeks on one philosopher to suddenly reading four different philosophers in one week.  The course could be improved by adjusting this balance and pacing a little.  

Also, I wish we had more of an introduction to philosophy at the beginning of the course, especially since some students came into the course with prior philosophy knowledge while others didn't.  We got a few handouts on how to write a philosophy paper, but for the first few weeks I felt confused as to what philosophy actually is.  It's true that you have to learn some skills by doing them, but I would have benefitted from a little more advice and explanation: what are the goals of philosophy, and what are its methods?  what things should you be looking for when you read a philosophy text?  what kinds of things should you be getting at during class discussion?

The lectures should focus more on developing a macro-view of the development of the course. The religious thinkers need more introduction and qualification, because they are very different, but also similar to the Greeks in important ways that I think, if explicated, could have positively influenced our discussions.
Good small class size and teacher engagement
There are no weaknesses!  I loved every minute of this course!

The lectures for philosophy were particularly useful compared to my other DS sections, as the philosophy texts often require more guidance to fully comprehend. I really enjoyed the seminar discussions because hearing the views of my classmates would often cause me to question my own views on a certain philosophical issue. I did find that the reading load varied more from week to week in philosophy than the other DS strands, which made it more difficult for me to plan my time accordingly and ensure that I completed all the reading.

The greatest strength is that David Charles instructs the class. His knowledge on the subjects discussed is outstanding, and his ability to create an inclusive class should be something all instructors should strive for. The only weakness I can think of is that it was not a longer class, as I thoroughly enjoyed each minute spent in it.

Evidently the circumstances of this year affected my experience of the course in such a way that it would be difficult for me to say what a "normal" experience would be like: online zoom seminars lack the immediacy of face-to-face interaction. Certainly the quality of my engagement was lower than what it would have been during an in-person class. Structurally, I lamented the fact that so much of the course, by the very nature of the syllabus, operated at a surface level; we had so many thinkers to get through that much of the ideas could only be remarked on briefly and discussed in one or two classes.

Strengths: I really enjoyed the discussions we had in this class. Professor Charles was really good at creating an environment where those discussions could occur and prompting us to think critically about the works we read, to make the discussions fruitful. 

Weaknesses: As I understand it this is a weakness of the entire DS Philosophy section, but I found the initial minimal guidance on how to write a philosophical essay was detrimental to my work.

Strengths - The material was very interesting and the seminars allowed us to really dive deep into the material and ask great questions.
Weaknesses - There wasn't a ton of support on the analytic writing end, which made the papers difficult.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Zoom worked well for class and office hours, but I wished we had used breakout rooms more.
All succeeded.
Online seminars worked well

It is easy to feel disconnected from the class while sitting behind a computer. This was not the case for this class. David was able to ensure that everyone was contributing to discussion, and kept everyone seemingly engaged. I felt that I had all the support I needed to succeed in this class during these times.
It would be better if there were an opportunity to watch the lectures synchronously as opposed to having only asynchronous lectures.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I would recommend this course to another student.  I think you have to be prepared to struggle through some of the readings, but class discussion is always really worthwhile.  The course teaches really important skills like critical thinking, analysis, and writing.
I would. The ideas we discuss will change the way you see the world and if you choose to engage deeply, you will be changed by the texts and the discussions with Professor Charles and your peers.
Yes
Yes!  There is definitely a learning curve to philosophy, but it is well worth the effort!  You leave the class with your horizons of thought and expression broadened in so many ways.

I would recommend this course to anyone who has an interest in philosophy, even if they have no experience in it. This course serves as a good introduction to Western philosophy and pushes students to compare different philosophers and critique their views rigorously.

I would undoubtedly recommend this class to anyone who wants to learn about philosophy. In an often gloomy semester, David Charles philosophy class was a constant beacon of light. I firmly believe it would be impossible to leave this class without feeling excited about philosophical ideas, and have found myself returning to the issues discussed even after class has ended.

Yes, I would. I found the works we studied really interesting and it was wonderful to learn under a Professor who both knew so much and was clearly dedicated to our success in understanding these works.
I would strongly recommend Professor Charles' DS class to anyone taking DS. He is a great teacher and you will learn a lot in this class.
